sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/helm/mariadb.message:
What happens in the case where a controller does not come back? For example, if you power down a controller without warning and leave it powered off.
Also, you need to test the cases where either the active or the standby controller is rebooted (or powered off). Have you tested both these cases?

StarlingX needs to be able to handle the loss of either controller and still be able to provide service. This is the case in the stx.2.0 release and we need to continue to provide that ability in stx.3.0. Any fix you make must take this into account - it isn't acceptable to have an outage until the second controller recovers.

Yes, It is valid to make StarlingX cluster work even only one controller alive and I validated this feature is there with starlingX 3.0.

As well, I tested this case by shutting down one Controller and mariadb was also working well. 

In fact, Looking into mariadb (galeracluster), it has considered this extreme case of losing nodes, by two options:
"evs.suspect_timeout" and "evs.inactive_timeout". 
In the current upsteam helm_infra for mariadb, evs.suspect_timeout is set PT30S, which means after 30S of the inactivity period, the node will be suspected as dead and it won't continue to sync up with the dead node until it comes alive again.

Again, back to my change, increasing readiness_failure_threshold just enhance the level of torrence in the exceptional cases (reboot or shutdown one of controllers), and won't bring any side effect if the cluster is recovered or one node is declared to be "inactive" or dead. On the other hand, if we don't increase this default threshold, K8S master will easily change the pod state from running to "NotReady" and get it rid of endpoint list and service list, whereas this pod is still functional. And as said, this will trigger a deadlock after the new pod comes out and tries to reach out to the peer.

In addition, another solution might be to disable the readinessProbe (as nova-scheduler does), but I don't think it is a better solution because in the normal cases, readiness probing by the checking mariadb WSREP status is a valuable way to assure WSREP among maraidb nodes.

If StarlingX was deployed with 2 controllers in the first place, and one controller never came back for whatever reasons, mariadb server would eventually claim to fail with the unavailability state. And I think this is the reasonable behavor, because the StarlingX deployment was destroyed.

About the test cases, yes, I tested these 2 cases (active controller or standby controller rebooted), and the mariadb cluster (a existing server + a newly joned one) can be recovered in both cases.

This increasing of FailureThreshold intends to make the alive mariadb pod wait longer time (periodic_time * failureThreshold). With the previous existing setting, peroidic_probe_interval was 30 seconds and default failureThreshold was 3 times, so totally it was only 90 seconds for the alive mariadb server to wait for another mariadb online which was way too short for a STX controller to reboot. Based on the experience, it might take 10+ minutes for a controller to reboot on a bare metal server. So I chose 30 as the threshold (which means the alive mariadb pod could wait for 30*30 seconds before it turns to "failed" state.). 
Here 30 is an empirical value. If you have better idea, please advise.
What units is this using? Seconds?
it means 30 times of readinessProbe failure at most are allowed before the pod changes its state from "running" to "failed"

.zuul.yaml.message: Name of this job and "override-checkout" is set to be run on rocky branch only but You are setting to use py3 here and description of the job says something opposite about this job :)

This is magic of the branch variant. 

So there are two things. 1. gate where this job is running 2. stable branch against which it will run

2nd is always stable/rocky as override-checkout: stable/rocky
1st can be: 
i) stable/rocky gate when this job running on neutron stable/rocky branch gate.
ii) master gate when this job is running on neutron-tempest-plugin gate which is master

For i) case, job defined in L248 (run on py2 because stable/rocky gate use py2 distro) will be used because of 'branches' var at L322.
For ii) case, job defined at L327 is used which will run on neutron-tempest-plugin master gate because this has to test things on py3 env now. You can see here[1].

Both job names has to be same so that zuul can pick up right version of it based on 'branches' variant. 

[1]
https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/fed59aa57aad4c369ff4bb11c3aa489b/log/controller/logs/pip3-freeze.txt
ok, I didn't know that zuul is so smart. Thx for explanation
the same here. And also this job has the same name as job defined above, which should use python 2.
this should be multinode
yes, thanks
this version of job does not have job variant so it match with the job for stable/rocky gate too. We need to explicitly set branches here too.

can we maybe split this patch into 2 parts? One with changes to job definition (this file basically) and merge it now and second (dropping py2 support) which will be merged after we will fix https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699213/ and https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705413/ to not release final version for rocky with 2 totally broken tests?
ok that make sense. fixing rocky job to run on master and py2 on stable/rocky gate is logically separate change which we should do while defaulting devstack to py3.

oslo_utils/imageutils.py.message:
I'm curious, does json output fix this? I'm wondering why we default to human when the description seems to suggest json is superior for this purpose.

If that disables the annoying output changes that qemu seems to like to introduce every few releases then I would push hard for that to be our new default. Maybe our lower-constraint for qemu is too old?

> I'm curious, does json output fix this? I'm wondering why we
 > default to human when the description seems to suggest json is
 > superior for this purpose.

Yes it does, it also makes improvements like I133da07a5a9628b8a9338556939c858afae679f4 much easier. We should definitely change the default to JSON sooner rather than later IMHO.

 > If that disables the annoying output changes that qemu seems to
 > like to introduce every few releases then I would push hard for
 > that to be our new default. Maybe our lower-constraint for qemu is
 > too old?

The only lower-constraint for QEMU that I'm aware of is in the code of the Libvirt driver within Nova. MIN_QEMU_VERSION currently sits at 2.11 and should be modern enough for us to default to JSON here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/270a61e749f346669c05675d51353116638c33ba/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L226

I totally agree with you and this is the way we chose with Lon to address the issue.

Lon proposed to move to json from the ironic side to avoid this kind of issue each new release.

Concerning the lower constraint I don't know I need to investiguate why to don't use it as the default.

I would rather not do this from Ironic. In fact, I'm not at all sure why we even made this configurable. It's an implementation detail internal to the class.

That said, fixing it with a regex will allow backporting if necessary so I'm good with merging this and switching to json separately.
I feel like we could just look for "e" in the value rather than introduce another regex. That would also eliminate the possibility of these two regexes getting out of sync.

I prefered used a regex here to avoid cases where notation could differ (1e+03 vs 1E+03 etc...) but we have 2 alternative to avoid to sync regexes, either we look for "e" on a lowercase'd string or we reuse fragment in the both side with something like:

```
SCI_NOTATION = '([0-9]+[eE][-+][0-9]+)'
SIZE_RE = re.compile(r"({SCI_NOTATION}|\d*\.?\d+)"
                      "\s*(\w+)?(\s*\(\s*(\d+)\s+bytes\s*\))?".format(SCI_NOTATION), re.I)
SCI_NOTATION_RE = re.compiler(r'{SCI_NOTATION}'.format(SCI_NOTATION))
```

My main concern is that scientific notation could differ, however I don't think that qemu will give us exotical output and notations and disk space should not be an outlier.

So I think you are right and we could easily look for "e" in a lowercase fashion.
Yep, sounds good. Hopefully we won't have to worry about this long-term anyway.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: nit: OpenStack (you capitalized OpenShift, so let's be consistent)

I see no linked ticket about the design proposal. As this is not a bug fix we first need to see what is missing from artcl.

I do not think that we really need to increase code complexity by having two different ways of deciding which files are to be collected.

Unless we find a very good reason, is better to have a single logic about this, using either rsync filters or find, but not both.

Two execution paths makes the code harder to test and the outcomes less predictable.

To better understand this we need a ticket and an example with both cases: a gives file structure, an include list, an exclude list,  a pure-rsync approach and find-with-rsync approach, one that can enable use to compare them.

> I see no linked ticket about the design proposal. As this is not a
 > bug fix we first need to see what is missing from artcl.
What ticket do you mean? To see what's different just the list of files I added can be compared with the default one in defaults/main.yml
But it's also not about the paths itself, the complexity (level) of every defined path matters as the list in defaults.main.yml is meant for rsync filter and the one I added in infrared_plugin is meant for find.

If you're against having an infrared related set of file paths defined inside infrared_plugin dir, I'll move them elsewhere outside of this repo, that's not a problem.

 > I do not think that we really need to increase code complexity by
 > having two different ways of deciding which files are to be
 > collected.
Well, the problem with just passing a list of paths to rsync is that rsync takes the paths literally: /var/log/ means, that only files in /var/log/ are rsynced, not directories in it and the whole subfolder structure. Therefore I find very practical to generate this list of paths dynamically. find is very helpfull there as we are able to limit the search based on subfolder level, file size and other options if needed later (see all find parameters).

So if we want to use just one way, I'd vote for find due to it's various options to control the search. BUT, that change could be tricky for tripleo jobs as the list of paths used by those jobs would lead to collecting much more files suddenly - because find search also includes subfolders - so it would require a little bit of tuning and looking for the correct mainly depth setting.

I was also experimenting for a while with porting the infrared's list of paths (currently added in infrared_plugin/artcl_collect_list.yml) to rsync but I ended up with many regexes (because i was trying to get collected also a few levels of subfolders of those paths). The file become harder to read and I still wasn't able to get the same files as I was getting using find.

 > Unless we find a very good reason, is better to have a single logic
 > about this, using either rsync filters or find, but not both.
 > 
 > Two execution paths makes the code harder to test and the outcomes
 > less predictable.
I wouldn't say so in this case, it's not like a whole path including many tasks is different. It's one task and it's quite readable from a glance at the code.

 > To better understand this we need a ticket and an example with both
 > cases: a gives file structure, an include list, an exclude list,  a
 > pure-rsync approach and find-with-rsync approach, one that can
 > enable use to compare them.
The above explanation should be enough, but later I may prepare some example CLI outputs if needed.

doc/source/developer/specs/scale-out-sch.message: Why would the active event gathering go into zuul-web? (Seems more appropriate for the passive one).
I think making it a deployers choice is unnecessary complexity. My preference is to keep it in the scheduler which can, after this spec, be scaled itself.

You're right, while this would be a possible lazy choice, the schedulers are probably the better place if one doesn't want to start a separate service for this. So I think we should leave this as a deployment choice if the user wants this inside the scheduler(s) or as separate services.
I was thinking the same thing, and I like it. But I'm also concerned we're over-valueing 100% ingestion.

Non-leaders could watch both the incoming and outgoing stream, keep a running history of the last X minutes of events which haven't made it into zookeeper, and, if they become leader, report those from the backlog.

It's a lot like B, but storing the data in memory twice (in the ingestor processes) instead of in ZK twice.

How about we start with pure leader election and support a standalong ingestor? That way we have most of the time ingestion and could later extend that to the 100% variant if we want to.

Thinking more about that, in case of connection drops and reconnects whithout a crash of the ingestor we can loose events. So if we want 100% ingestion we would also need to cancel leadership instead of a reconnect.

Dedupe by hash is actually the perfect strategy. Don't even store an event if it already exists. Ordering them can be a bit complex though, as the receivers will need to keep track of which event they got previously and assign an order counter when they write, but if they don't write because the record already exists, they need to ensure that they adapt their ordering properly. I believe we've *almost* reimplemented Kafka at that point.

Is the stream implemented as a safe messaging system? IIRC, it's just a stream, and as such, messages will be sent if there are subscribers, and if not, they just go into the bit bucket. As such I'd say it's got to be expected that we might miss messages (such as when the ingestors are partitioned from Gerrit), and so just keeping the ingestor light, reliable, and consistent with a very low leader election/lock timeout would be the simplest course.

We could consider not supporting multiple ingestors, and instead make them standalone processes which are very small and quick to restart.  I think this would be acceptable, but if we can do A or B, we should.  They degrade to this case anyway if you only run one.
I think we should start with a simple leader election approach.
s/Guthub/Github/

Did you mean to remove the "it won't harm" phrase here?
I think I can remove the whole sentence as this was written under the assumption that the receiver performs deduplication where it's actually better to do this on the writer side.
by a?
will fix

I think as little as possible should be in ZK. If it can be re-calculated in a small amount of time, it should just be in memory, but if it's something large like the global config, it makes sense to maintain a consistent cache for schedulers to share and not have to re-fetch all the git trees.

It sounds like we're pretty close to agreement on this.  Yes, when I said "global parsed config" I did mean the "per branch parsed config".  That is -- the thing where we read in the YAML from every repo and store it as a python dictionary (obviously, that turns into a ZK json blob).  But there is no tenant information and it hasn't been turned into zuul.model objects yet.  It's more or less just a cache of what's in the repos.

I think it would be okay to store one copy of this -- I don't think we need to store a copy for each tenant.  We can "lock" the global config when someone is updating it so that if anyone needs to generate a tenant config, they will wait until the update is complete.  Then, obviously, once it is updated and unlocked, all components should regenerate their tenant config(s).

This is where the biggest unanswered questions are.

Are you suggesting we store the parsed config as a single object, or is that just the root, and under there we would have ".../jobs/..." etc?

We can still store the parsed branch config globally.  When a change happens, we can just lock the global config and whoever gets the lock gets to update it.

If we only store the global config, should we also store per-tenant configs?  Should they reference global config objects "by reference" (eg, znode ids?).

Same question for dynamic layouts (ie, per-change configs).

In general, these suggest two ends of a spectrum: storing a lot of config in zk, or storing very little.  If we store the global parsed config, per-tenant layout, and (where necessary) per-change layout, we'll be storing a lot in ZK.

If we wanted to store as little as possible, I'd suggest only storing the global parsed config in zk, and then have each scheduler process generate its own copy of the per-tenant config (whenever the underlying objects or configuration changed).  The zuul-web process could do the same so that it sees the same view of the data.  And whenever a dynamic layout is needed, the scheduler which is processing that pipeline at the time can generate the dynamic layout, keep it in memory until it has finished the pipeline, then discard it (after having recorded the frozen jobs in ZK).

The middle ground is probably closer to what you describe -- keep both the global and per-tenant configs in zk (perhaps with objects by reference), but don't store dynamic layouts in ZK.  That has the best scaling performance too (in that it doesn't cause ZK to scale eponentially with change volume).

My thinking was that we store the per branch parsed config (which you are referring to as global config?) as json blobs under this path. This way we can quickly recalculate the layout of a tenant without having to save too much data in zk which we should avoid. I suggested to store this under a tenant specific path in order to not having to care about race conditions when reconfiguring several tenants sharing a few shared at the same time. I'm not sure if that's a problem so that's just pure precaution. We also can keep that really global and protect the updates with locks per project. That way we don't serialize reconfigurations of several tenants.

The per tenant config (current non dynamic layout) could be easily cached in memory and updated by each scheduler based on the version and cversion (child version) of each project that is part of the tenant. In case a version or cversion changed, we would need to inject a tenant reconfiguration (possibly without asking the mergers) to rebuild the layout of the tenant.

Regarding the dynamic layout. I also thought that we should just store the frozen jobs in zk as part of the pipeline state. After that we probably don't need the dynamic layout so there should be no need to store it in zk.
+1 for that, I think it's clear that the DB isn't quite in the right place as a reporter anyway.
Or, we could make the SQL database integrated (ie, not a reporter) and drop the times database.
The SQL database can accomplish what the time database is used for.  It would just be a very simple query to get the last 10 runtimes for successful runs of a tenant-project-branch-job.

I agree. I think for a while we've known that we'll likely require some kind of database to run zuul. We may even choose something that isn't SQL, but that is a topic for another spec. I think it would be safe to assume for this spec that some sort of database is both required and available. I also think that this change should be part of v4.

+1 for moving sql reporting into zuul itself. But I'm not sure if we should move the times database into sql. I hadn't yet a really close look into how it exactly works yet. I just saw that the times database consists of small binary files per project/branch/job.

It's possible that everything you wrote here could apply to "pipelines" rather than tenants.  I think we should seek to have parallel pipeline processors within a tenant, not just parallel tenant processing.  Fortunately, I think that's not a big change from this.

We might accomplish this by having the trigger event processor dispatch to tenant+pipeline rather than just tenant.

Right, I'll change that. This makes the management events slightly more complex but I think that's ok. These events like reconfigure or tenant-reconfigure typically operate on tenant level. So we might need an rw lock on the tenant and a normal lock on the pipeline. A pipeline would lock both, a management event would only lock the tenant lock.
+1 for locking on the pipeline.

I'd like for the scheduler to also encrypt the keys on disk so I don't have to use encrypted volumes. But that's a story for another day. Suffice to say that you're right, the trust levels are the same, but I'm holding new development to a higher standard.

IMO it's not enough to have auth and TLS. We will need to keep those secrets encrypted in ZK, since writing anything to ZK means it will be in the ZK transaction log, unlike gearman which keeps the queues in memory. We can have the executors place a public key into ZK, and schedulers then re-encrypt job secrets to that key upon an executor claiming the job.

Ok, so we should at least encrypt the secrets inside zk with a symmetric cipher (e.g. aes?). I think using public keys will be complicated as this involves a lot of additional round trips when we have multiple schedulers and exeuctors that need secrets or private keys.

Interesting point, but this assumes that you can trust your zookeeper less than your scheduler (as it stores the private keys unencrypted)? Is that really a problem (as we do trust the disks of the scheduler)?
It's /zuul/events/...

Thinking out loud would another option be to avoid leader election and allow every active event gatherer process to listen for and write events. We would then dedup via a hash of each event whcih could be locked for before writing the event data.

One drawback to this appraoch is it is computationally more expensive, but should avoid losing any events if you restart one process at a time.

Yes, I had this in the first version as an option. But I think it's much more complex than simple leader election and could be an enhancement after the scale out implementation. So I think this doesn't need to be in the scope of this spec.

Thinking about this more I'm not sure how feasible this is as we'd need to keep a record of every event processed for some potentially long period of time in order to check in the future if some event we've received is a duplicate.

We might be able to avoid that issue with hashes if we can guarantee that all of the events we are receiving already come with some monotonically increasing identifier value (then its a simple < or > comparison). I don't know that we can rely on that for all potential event inputs so the leader election design may be simplest.
I think we probably end up storing the unparsed config too(or only). This is needed for efficient tenant reconfigurations which will be done distributed.

As mentioned on PS2 (but after you updated to PS4), I think we should only store the global project-branch config in ZK.  I don't think we need to do so per-tenant.  I think if we just use it as a cache of JSON representing the YAML in files, then each component can generate per-tenant configs from the ZK data.  We can use locking to avoid race conditions.  This lets us store the minimum necessary in ZK.

Clark, asking for the content from the mergers is time-consuming and not something that every component should need to do, which is why I think that at least (but also, at most) we should store the read zuul.yaml data (the global project-branch config) in ZK.  It's not clear to me whether you support that or not, but I think it's important.

Beyond that, yes, I imagine essentially a checkpoint system (was this tenant config generated from the current global config sequence number, or a previous one? if previous, it's invalid, need to update) would work well.

I was mostly brainstorming ways to avoid storing much data in zk and was semi familiar with how kafka does it (I mean at a high level I've never read the code).

If we think the cost of many git merges is worse than zk storing some data (likely is given git mergers are computations) then this setup with checkpoints off of the yaml data would work well.
Ok, that makes sense. So we could store the global config per project and branch in distinct objects (because the max blob size is by default 1MB) but lock and checkpoint the complete global config.

I believe that the way kafka does this is to only record journal type data in zookeeper and refer to the external source of truth as necessary to roll things through the system.

Applying a similar appraoch to Zuul I think we could record canonical repo locations and branch/sha1 data in zk to represent the most up to date config and if a local scheduler's config is behind that sha1 we update to it.

For updates we would have events (driven by the active and passive event handling above) that would update the sha1 in zk.

I don't know that this is necessarily better than what is proposed above but would minimize the data stored in zk.
Everything is worse without SQL.  We should just use it.
We need to move the time database out of the filesystem, so let's make "drop the time database and require SQL" part of this effort.  I don't think we should use zk for it.
Is it feasible to require SQL db for time db, but continue to make the SQL db optional?
ok, that makes sense. I'll change that.

Thinking more about that I think we'll still need an execution request similar to the node requests in nodepool as a queue at a specific location. Otherwise all executors will have to do permanent searches over all pipelines. Further in order to keep the event based approach the executor probably needs to add finished/updated events to the respective pipeline event queues.

Thinking more about that I think we'll still need an execution request similar to the node requests in nodepool as a queue at a specific location. Otherwise all executors will have to do permanent searches over all pipelines. Further in order to keep the event based approach the executor probably needs to add finished/updated events to the respective pipeline event queues.

We may want to capture how we expect to recover in the event of losing an executor. If that happens the running job state is lost and we need to restart the jobs with new nodesets.

I think this means we need to have watches for the executor locks on the schedulers? And handle that lock going away without job completed data in the data structure? And then we want to be able to handle this in multiple schedulers? Anyways it seems sufficiently complicated that we may want something written down here about how we can handle it.
I'll think more about that and extend this.
Let's wait and see if that's a problem; the max processing time sounds complex and I don't think it should be necessary.

This depth first approach may also starve other pipelines and tenants. Do we need to rotate in a breadth first fashion instead to ensure events coming in sufficiently quickly prevent us from processing another tenant or pipeline?

The event loop is expected to loop fast as it is already the case. Further I'd expect multiple pipeline processor threads per scheduler so that might be less of a problem. But we could add a max processing time as a safety net that forces switching to the next tenant after some threshold.
Setting things up in the kafka model as described above may simplify this? We wouldn't need to store any secrets in zk, but would need to share keys.

That's exactly the case here. We share keys to decrypt the secret stuff (like secrets or kubernetes credentials from nodepool). Not everything will be necessarily somewhere in git. Further doing cat operations for every dereference is much more complicated and expensive.

This raises some concerns for me. Notably:

* Lots of events (which we are sure to have) will cause event sequence numbers to rollover. Could that put a wrinkle in processing the events in order?

* Assuming you plan to use the kazoo queue recipe, that is documented to be buggy, causing memory leaks over long periods of usage. https://kazoo.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/recipe/queue.html#module-kazoo.recipe.queue

We could look a little harder at dropping these event queues.  Zuul 1.0's scheduler was very much event-driven, with the idea that if, say, a build finished, we only needed to look at that queue item.  But that was error-prone, and Zuul has gotten much more complex since then.  Now we do some actions on events, but not very much, and mostly we just use the events to set a flag saying "run the pipeline queue processor".  We might be able to do the things we need to do quickly with watches on objects and otherwise just run the queue processor.  If folks think this approach is worthwhile, I can take a closer look at the current queues and figure out how we could rearrange them.

We can also segment it if necessary.  /zuul/config/project/branch/jobs/ could be a directory of json blobs.  We wouldn't need to make one zobject per job -- we would end up with too many zobjects that way.  But we could have /zuul/config/project/branch/jobs/1 be the first 100 jobs, and jobs/2 be the next 100.  That way we remove the size limitation, and when small changes happen in big repos, we reduce the amount of data we need to change in zk (for example, we might only replace the jobs/2 object if job #157 is updated).
I like this idea

I would worry that if the compression's purpose it to fit certain limit size turning it off may cause some problems (in case of e.g. debugging). Therefore maybe a more broken up format, i.e., the one mentioned above may be a better approach.
I feel like with the API and dashboard allowing flexible queries (including pipeline), we've largely superceded any use like that.
Is there a reason to still have sql reporters in pipelines?  Why not just attach them in tenants (so different tenants can use different sql connections, but each tenant always uses exactly one)?

Ok, I'm happy to remove the sql reporters from the pipeline config entirely. So we could define an sql connection as default in zuul.conf and make it possible to override it per tenant in the tenant config.

Since the purpose of this is High-Availability shouldn't we think about some HA-Store. An SQL database feels a bit like a possible future bottleneck here when multiple, possibly many, schedulers will try to write there simultaneously.
The reason was mostly backwards compatibility as today one can choose to report per pipeline. But I'm open to just remove this as this is probably just a hypothetical use case.

If the purpose of this is to know the times of last 10 successful builds wouldn't it be worth to think about storing  it in Zookeeper too. And by that limiting the complexity of both, code and deployment - less mandatory deployment nodes?
We anyway store all builds in the db. However we should think about caching those times to not overload the db because of that.

I don't think we should include the max processing time to start with; I think that will introduce a lot of edge cases we would need to handle and complexity.  If we find we need it we can add it later.
Good point. I'll add this. If we can manage it (and I hope this works out) I'd be in favor of a series of moderate changes instead of a big bang release.

We should probably add a section on work items.  It would be good to list some of the major steps we need to do, so we can get an idea of how much work will need to be done, whether we can split it up among different authors, and how we should handle merging and releasing.

Particularly, it would be good to figure out whether we want to break it up into a series of moderate changes (such as "require sql", "zk ingestor", "zk executor", "zk scheduler"), each of which gets a 3.x release with an upgrade note, or whether we want to maintain a long stack of changes in gerrit with rebasing and land it all then release 4.0, or whether we want to make a feature branch.  I think making the list of work items as a start will help us find the right answer.

0: It's probably worth noting that we would also have /nodesets/ etc for the other config object types.

This does mean there will be a small amount of additional processing needed to split the raw yaml into chunks corresponding to the config objects.  That shouldn't be too hard.

-1: I missed the use case for multiple databases per tenant.  I think we should only have one sql connection per tenant.  I don't see the purpose of having more than one, and we've already seen that having more than one is fairly complicated to deal with.

If someone has a use-case for more than one database/connection per tenant, let's describe it here so we know why we're supporting the extra complexity.  Otherwise, let's simplify this so that there is a single one per tenant (and it doesn't need to be specified if there is a global default).
One sql connection per zuul or per tenant should covers all of our use-cases.

Originally the SQL reporter was just that - a reporter. Thus being able to choose where the results went (much like you can choose with the smtp reporter) was useful. For example, it was a way to get results out of zuul so that you could then do your own analysis. This might have been done by putting a job you were interested in in a pipeline just for this purpose (eg an `sql-pipeline`).

Obviously now zuul does a lot more with the information out of the reporter. So the question I think we should look at is even if it is considered a reporter. The "primary database" connection described here alludes to something slightly different to a reporter.

So a single SQL connection for a tenant I think is enough, and a requirement, to achieve what zuul needs to with the data. Specifically this is internal to zuul's needs and it is debatable if it should even be exposed as a reporter.

Then there is an obvious regression and the question becomes if we should keep SQL reporters, and specifically ones that can use an alternative SQL connection/database.

I think there is an argument to be made that this is still useful. However, I also think it can be separate from this spec and implemented as a standalone reporter at some point.

But to go further than that, it is likely that any argument or use case made in favour of a separate database can be implemented by other means. For example, by using cross-database views, or by writing a small script to pull out the parts you need from the master database into your analysis database etc.

Therefore, I would suggest that only 1 connection is appropriate and necessary for this spec. I would also suggest investigating not exposing it as a reporter, but just an assumed function, as zuul has expectations about what is actually in the database.

I think it's out of scope for this spec - but fdegir has requested resumable executors before... he's got jobs that sometimes run for several days so an executor interruption is costly for him like a scheduler is for everyone. While I don't think we need to account for that in this spec - maybe it's worth noting that it could be a followup ... and executors over zookeeper are likely an important step towards being able to think about that.
0/-1? We don't even really need an election, right?  We can just have all the schedulers fight for the lock.  (I guess that's a form of leader election?  Just a very simple one.)

-1: I think the only time this would help is when we're waiting on merger jobs in a reconfiguration.  The rest of the time we will be CPU-bound with the GIL and therefore more threads will only hurt.  So we might want to plan on only having a single pipeline processer in a scheduler, but perhaps handle reconfigurations in a second thread.

I just realized a problem with this.  We now support different tenants reading different files, so we still need to store the unparsed config by files.  I see the following options:

1) Add in a filename to the path (eg /zuul/config/<project>/<branch>/<filename>/jobs/1)
2) Add the filename and drop the object type (eg /zuul/config/<project>/<branch>/<filename>/1), and just shard when the raw string data gets near 1MB.

I lean slightly toward #2.  The downside is that in the case of a large file, a change in the 999th KB would require rewriting objects /1 and /2, because we're not breaking on a semantic boundary but rather mere byte boundaries.

On the other hand, most files are probably *much* smaller than that (openstack's projects.yaml is 137k), so we're unlikely to need to shard anyway since we're splitting by files.  This is probably easier to implement too, since it's close to the current cache system.
Done
Done

Come to think of it, we should really move the mergers to ZK too -- we need to get rid of gearman in order to remove all spofs.  We should add one more section about that (it should be easy though, it's just a simple job queue).
Fine for me, I'd like to get rid of it too. We initially kept this in the spec because I think there was some opposition about completely getting rid of gearman.
Done
I'm confused why this was moved to future work; isn't this very much in scope?  The gearman job is only held by one scheduler, so a scheduler restart would lose the connection to the build.
I got the idea from a comment on last patch that we may do something later on. Probably just got confused.
Actually I have no idea why I put this here as I can clearly remember a discussion about this on irc back then. we'll move this to the main part of the spec
I will change that to to <path-to-config> since <filename> is not enough here and may be misleading here.
Indeed, "<filename>" might be a value like "zuul.d/jobs.yaml".  So whatever we have to do to support that.  :)
Done

One thing that has created some confusion with nodepool node request priorities is that they are sorted alphanumerically and not by integer value.

I think we should be consistent in the priority system we use here to avoid further confusion.

When we get to the point where this has been implemented we should try to remember to document the behavior. I think this has the possibility of changing current expected behavior for existing users and helping them understand why jobs are scheduled in some order will help them. At the very least it will help me field questions when they come up :)
